Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative research: Exploring the generality of light, nutrient and predator constraints on food chain efficiency
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research will examine how the efficiency of energy flow through food webs is affected by sunlight, nutrients, and predators. Sunlight and nutrients affect the chemical composition of algae, including the amounts and ratios of carbon, nitrogen and phosphorus as well as essential fatty acids (EFAs). In addition, light and nutrients can determine which algal species are present, and their digestibility for herbivores. Variation in carbon:nutrient ratios, EFAs, and digestion resistance of algae can determine the production of herbivores, but little is known about how these effects propagate to animals at the top of the food chain, e.g., fish and other carnivores.

The investigators will conduct three large-scale experiments to investigate effects of light, nutrients, carnivore species, food web structure, and nutrient ratios on food chain efficiency. They will also develop next-generation, stoichiometrically-explicit computer models which will provide mechanistic understanding of the experimental results, and expand the scope of the research.

This project will provide critical information for decision-makers involved in water quality protection and fisheries management. For example, fisheries yields depend on food chain efficiency, specifically the proportion of algae production that is converted into fish or shellfish species harvested by humans; eutrophication results from the inefficient use of plant production by herbivores after excessive nutrient enrichment; carbon storage in deep waters and sediments (which reduces greenhouse gases in the atmosphere) is related to energy that is not consumed in pelagic food chains; and the concentrations of contaminants at each trophic level is affected by energy flow through food chains. In addition, many global-scale environmental problems, such as eutrophication and climate change, alter the supplies of light and nutrients, and can mediate food chain efficiency. In addition the project will provide numerous opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students, who will be actively engaged in all aspects of the research.

DEB 0949547

Spencer R. Hall, Indiana University

 

Collaborative research: Exploring the generality of light, nutrient and predator constraints on food chain efficiency

 

 

In the Indiana portion of this collaborative grant, we used mathematical models to study flow of energy from primary producers (like plants) to grazers of those producers to predators (carnivores). Using verbal/conceptual models, our collaborative group hypothesized that supply of light and nutrients to ecosystems might strongly govern flow of energy up this 'food chain'. In particular, we envisioned that certain supply of these key resources might create highly nutritious plants that enhance flow of energy, while other ratios of supply of these resources might inhibit flow of energy by creating food of poor nutrition. Experimentally, our collaborators discovered that supply of light and nutrients to pond ecosystems did not strongly influence flow of energy in these predicted days; instead, rates of primary production essentially controlled subsequent flow up the food chain in simple and predictable ways. Our modeling explains this 'energy-limited' result. We show that predators that strongly depress grazers create these simpler 'energy-limited' scenarios. Similarly, increased defenses by primary producers from grazing behave in a similar manner. Thus, strong control of grazers by their predators or by strong defenses by plants - factors important in nature and our group's experiments - simplifies theory for energy flow up food chains. These modeling efforts, then, enhance our ability to predict production of carnivores based on supply of nutrients and light to ecosystems.

 

The Indiana portion of the grant also broadened theoretical understanding of two other suites of issues. First, it enhanced understanding of the ecological and evolutionary factors that maintain diversity of species in environments that vary in the ratios of the resources that those species consume. We found that supply of key resources (nitrogen, phosphorus, and light) did not promote diversity (species richness) of phytoplankton as some ecological models predict. Instead, diverse groups of grazers (zooplankton) did explain it - grazers can double diversity of coexisting phytoplankton in experiments, helping to resolved the long-standing 'paradox of the plankton'. Additionally, using mathematical models again, we found that variation in supply of resources to species can allow persistence of species in evolutionary time (A) in certain nutritional situations which are likely not found often in nature, but (B) for certain types of consumers of those resources that can strategically chose where to locate themselves in their habitat. Second, we developed new mathematical models of species in which juveniles (young) compete with adults. We aimed to develop those models to better connect variation in nutritional quality of food resources with dynamics of species (in other words, how they change through time). While that work is still in progress, we discovered along the way that (C) disease epidemics can cause populations to begin to fluctuate more or less wildly, depending on how disease infection affects juveniles vs. adults, and (D) differences between juveniles and adults can greatly enhance the ability of two species to coexist on one resource. This latter result is very important because it helps resolve a disconnect between simpler mathematical models (which predict that it is hard for two species to coexist on one resource because a stronger competitor usually wins by driving the other extinct) vs. observations (where many species seem to coexist on only a handful of resources).

 

Thus, the Indiana portion of the grant produced mathematical models that enhance our understanding of how energy moves up food chains from primary producers to carnivores. Our results clarify why this flow likely does not depend sensitively on relative supply of nutrients and light to ecosystems. Thus, it becomes much easier to predict production of carnivores in various environments. Additionally, this model clarified how different types of resources do not necessarily enhance coexistence of species strongly. Finally, addition of 'stage structure' - specifically, competition of adults and their offspring for shared food - can greatly improve our understanding of disease epidemics and coexistence of species.
